intro: Crataegus thyrsoidea, commonly known as the thyrsoidean hawthorn, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to eastern North America. It typically grows to a height of 3–8 meters and features thorny branches, which are characteristic of the genus Crataegus. The plant produces white to pink flowers in early spring, followed by red or orange berries in the fall. Its leaves are ovate to elliptic, with serrated edges, and it thrives in full sun to partial shade. This species is often found in woodland edges, thickets, and along streambanks, contributing to local biodiversity.
